title: Bayes' Theorem
text: The probability of event A given event B may be computed by means of the following formula: P(A$$\mid$$B)=P(A)P(B$$\mid$$A)/P(B)

title: Events
text: Let N be the hypothesis "your door does not have a car behind it," and E be the evidence that Monty has revealed a door with a goat behind it. Then the problem can be restated as calculating P(N$$\mid$$E)=P(N)P(E$$\mid$$N)/P(E)

title: P(N)
text: What is the probability that your door does not have a car behind it before Monty reveals a goat? Enter your answer as a fraction

subHints.title: P(H)
subHints.text: Without knowing about the door that Monty reveals, there are 3 possible doors and your door is just 1 of them, so there are 2 outcomes where the car is not behind your door. Thus P(N) is $$\frac{2}{3}$$

title: P(E$$\mid$$N)
text: What is the probability that Monty shows a door with a goat behind it, given that there is a goat behind your door?

subHints.title: P(E$$\mid$$N)
subHints.text: Since Monty always shows a door with a goat, the probability that Monty shows a door with a goat behind it, given that there is a goat behind your door, is 1

title: P(E)
text: What is the probability that Monty shows a door with a goat behind it?

subHints.title: P(E)
subHints.text: Since Monty always shows a door with a goat, the probability that Monty shows a door with a goat behind it is 1

title: P(N$$\mid$$E)
text: Use P(N), P(E$$\mid$$N), and P(E) to solve for P(N$$\mid$$E) using Bayes' Theorem

title: Alternative Approach
text: The probability that the car is behind your door is completely unchanged by the evidence. However, since the car can only either be behind your door or behind the door Monty didn't reveal, the probability that it is behind the door that is not revealed is $$1-\frac{1}{3}=\frac{2}{3}$$ .Therefore, switching is twice as likely to get you the car as sticking with your door.
